lessons.title: Welcome to Piano
lessons.description: Learn the basics of piano and get familiar with the keyboard layout
objectives: Learn about white and black keys

content.theoryText: The piano keyboard consists of white and black keys arranged in a repeating pattern. Each white key represents a natural note (C, D, E, F, G, A, B), while black keys represent sharps and flats. The pattern repeats across the keyboard, with each repetition called an octave.
tips: Look for groups of 2 and 3 black keys to find your way around
Middle C is usually near the center of the keyboard
Take your time to get familiar with the layout

lessons.title: Understanding the Keyboard
lessons.description: Master the keyboard layout and learn to identify notes quickly

content.theoryText: The piano keyboard is organized in octaves. Each octave contains 7 white keys (C, D, E, F, G, A, B) and 5 black keys. The pattern repeats, making it easier to navigate once you understand it. Middle C (C4) is your reference point.
tips: Use the groups of black keys as landmarks
C is always to the left of the group of 2 black keys
F is always to the left of the group of 3 black keys

lessons.title: Your First Note: Middle C
lessons.description: Learn to play Middle C with proper finger position
objectives: Find Middle C on the keyboard

content.theoryText: Middle C (C4) is the most important reference point on the piano. It's located near the center of the keyboard, to the left of the group of two black keys. Use your thumb (finger 1) to play it. Keep your hand relaxed and fingers curved.
tips: Keep your wrist level with your hand
Curve your fingers as if holding a ball
Press the key firmly but gently
Listen to the sound you create

lessons.title: Playing D and E
lessons.description: Expand your range by learning D and E notes
objectives: Play D and E notes correctly

content.theoryText: D and E are the next two white keys after Middle C. Use finger 2 (index) for D and finger 3 (middle) for E. Practice moving smoothly between C, D, and E. This is the beginning of playing melodies!
tips: Keep your fingers curved over the keys
Move smoothly from one note to the next
Practice slowly at first
Maintain even volume across all notes

lessons.title: Complete C Major Scale
lessons.description: Learn the complete C Major scale - the foundation of piano playing
objectives: Play all notes in C Major scale
Use correct fingering for the scale

content.theoryText: The C Major scale consists of 8 notes: C, D, E, F, G, A, B, C. It's the most fundamental scale in music and contains no sharps or flats. The fingering is: 1-2-3-1-2-3-4-5 (thumb crosses under after finger 3).
tips: Start slowly and focus on evenness
The thumb crosses under smoothly after E
Keep your hand relaxed throughout
Practice ascending and descending

lessons.title: Understanding Sharps and Flats
lessons.description: Learn about black keys and how they work
objectives: Learn the relationship between white and black keys

content.theoryText: Black keys are called sharps or flats. A sharp (#) raises a note by a half step, while a flat (♭) lowers it. For example, C# is the black key to the right of C, and D♭ is the same key (they're enharmonic equivalents). Black keys are played with fingers 2, 3, or 4.
tips: Use the tips of your fingers for black keys
Black keys are slightly higher than white keys
Each black key has two names (sharp and flat)
Practice moving between white and black keys smoothly

lessons.title: F and G Notes
lessons.description: Complete your first octave by learning F and G
objectives: Understand their position in the scale
Play simple melodies using all learned notes

content.theoryText: F and G complete the lower part of the scale. F is the white key to the left of the group of 3 black keys, and G is the next white key. These notes, combined with C, D, and E, allow you to play many simple melodies.
tips: F is easy to find - left of 3 black keys
Practice the sequence C-D-E-F-G
Try playing simple melodies
Focus on smooth transitions
